data.title: Benjamin Harrison Papers
data.meta_description: A chronology of key events in the life of Benjamin Harrison (1833-1901), U.S. senator from Indiana, U.S. Army officer, and twenty-third president of the United States.
data.text:
1833, Aug. 20

Born, North Bend, Ohio, the son of John Scott Harrison (1804-1878) and Elizabeth Irwin Harrison (1810-1850). His siblings were Elizabeth "Bessie" or "Betsy" Short Harrison Eaton (1825-1904), William Henry Harrison (1827-1829), Sarah "Sallie" Lucretia Harrison Devin (1829-1917), Archibald Irwin Harrison (1832-1870), Mary Jane "Jennie" Irwin Harrison Morris (1836-1867), Anna Symmes Harrison (1837-1838), John Irwin Harrison (1839-1839), Carter Bassett Harrison (1840-1905), Anna Symmes Harrison Morris (1842-1926), John Scott Harrison, Jr. (1844-1926), James Findlay Harrison (1847-1848), and James Irwin Harrison (1849-1850). His great-grandfather, Benjamin Harrison (1726-1791) of Virginia, signed the Declaration of Independence. His grandfather, William Henry Harrison (1773-1841), briefly served as the ninth president of the United States prior to his death on April 4, 1841, just thirty-one days into his term of office.

1852, June 24

B.A., Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, at which he was a member of the Phi Delta Theta fraternity and Union Literary Society

1858, Apr. 3

Daughter Mary Scott "Mamie" Harrison McKee born (d. Oct. 28, 1930). Her son Benjamin Harrison McKee (1887-1958) was famous during the Harrison administration as the "Baby McKee" on whom President Harrison doted.

1865, July-1869, Jan.

Reporter, Indiana Supreme Court (Harrison had been elected in October 1864, but resumed his duties following his military discharge in June 1865.)

1871, May

Appointed by President Ulysses S. Grant to defend General Alvin P. Hovey in the U.S. Circuit Court case ex parte Milligan, a suit for damages brought by Lambdin P. Milligan resulting from his wartime prosecution for disloyalty by a military commission in Indiana. While the jury ruled in favor of Milligan on principle, Harrison's prosecution succeeded in reducing the damages awarded to a token amount, and enhanced Harrison's legal reputation.

1874-1875

Built house at 1230 North Delaware Street, Indianapolis, Ind., which would later be the site of his "front porch" campaign for the presidency in 1888.

1877, Nov. 1

Death of former Indiana governor and U.S. senator Oliver P. Morton allowed Harrison to become the leader of the Indiana Republican Party.

1878, May 26

Death of father John Scott Harrison. On May 31, grave robbers stole his corpse to sell to the Ohio Medical College in Cincinnati, but the body was discovered prior to dissection.

1890

Wife Caroline Harrison became the first president general of the National Society Daughters of the American Revolution, now known as the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR)

1890

Congress passed the Dependent and Disability Pension Act, which expanded pension eligibility for Civil War veterans (June), Sherman Anti-Trust Act (July), Sherman Silver Purchase Act (July), and McKinley Tariff Act (September)

1890, July

Idaho and Wyoming achieved statehood. With the admission of four states in 1889, Harrison signed more statehood admissions than any other U.S. president.

1890, Dec.

Farmers' Alliance meeting in Florida gave rise to agrarian political activity, inspiring the formation of the People's or Populist Party that would participate in the 1892 election

1891, Jan.

Congress failed to pass the Federal Elections Bill (or "Force Bill") proposed by Republicans in 1890 to combat voter suppression, particularly of white Republicans and African American voters in the South. Harrison had supported this legislation.

1891, Mar. 3

Signed into law the Forest Reserve Act authorizing the president to establish forest reserves. Harrison used this law to set aside millions of acres in the western states.

1891, April 14-May 15

Five-week tour of the South and West (See scrapbook 10 in Series 16 for newspaper clippings documenting the trip.)

1892, July

Labor strikes began at the Coeur d'Alene mines in Idaho and Homestead Steel Works near Pittsburgh, Penn., the latter pitting the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers against the Carnegie Steel Company

1892, July-Sept.

Caroline Harrison stayed at Loon Lake in the Adirondack Mountains in New York in an attempt to improve her health. President Harrison visited frequently, and took a relatively inactive role in his presidential reelection campaign.

1895, Jan.-May

Plaintiffs' attorney in legal case regarding the estate of James L. Morrison, Richmond, Ind. Harrison won the case and collected a $25,000 fee. (See Case 57, Series 11 of the Harrison Papers for documents relating to the "Morrison will case")

1896, Apr. 6

Married Mary "Mame" Scott Lord Dimmick (Apr. 30, 1858-Jan. 5, 1948), daughter of Russell F. Lord (1802-1867) and Elizabeth Mayhew Scott Lord (1828-1889). Mary Dimmick was the niece of Harrison's first wife, Caroline Scott Harrison. Dimmick's first husband, Walter Dimmick, died in January 1882, less than three months after their wedding.
